chapter.title: Augusta Vision Statement
chapter.para: In this section we outline the philosophy and long range goals of Augusta. By doing so we put Augusta in context and sketch an overall vision for the project. The vision is intended to guide the project's development and be the source of its requirements.

listitem.para: Augusta should be constructed in a modular fashion so that it can be effectively called as a library from other applications. Augusta should support developers of Ada tools by exposing independent components, such as the parser and type checker, as well defined modules with clean, documented interfaces.
Augusta should support being used from modern IDEs using whatever means and protocols are appropriate to do so.
Augusta should support ASIS or whatever similar system is enjoying wide industry support (libadalang?).
Augusta should support an extension architecture so that users can extend the compiler in useful ways in a well defined manner.
Augusta should be designed from the ground up to take advantage of modern hardware by using parallelism and distributed computing when appropriate.
Augusta should be a "compiler writer's compiler," optionally exposing various compiler internals that might be of interest to the power user.

Augusta should attempt to be compatible enough with GNAT so that one could easily port a GNAT project to Augusta. On the other hand Augusta shouldn't be slavishly compatible with GNAT and should develop its own approach to doing things where appropriate.

Augusta should attempt to integrate the Ada, Scala, and LLVM communities. It should, to the greatest extent possible, follow the best practices of all these communities and attempt to create a "comfortable common ground" for potential contributors from these communities.
